oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poems
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Brooke, Rupert , 1887-1915
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1st ed. Keynes, Brooke, 5.
Bookplate of Jessie Stillman Taylor.
From the library of B. George Ulizio.

From the Shaw bibliography: This first volume of poetry by the young Brooke (1887-1915) was praised in review by Edward Thomas. The undulations of Brooke's literary reputation reflect well the changes in taste and ideology of English and American poetry in this century. Right after the war, Graves pointedly excluded Brooke from his list of three best poets to have fallen on the English side of the war. In 1917 Brooke served for the dedicatory poem of MacDonald and Ford's "Crown of Amaranth," offered for the poets who had fallen during the war. And in 1965 I.M. Parson, in "Men Who March Away," said that the "1914" sonnets "suffer from crippling shallowness of feeling."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poems and songs of patriotism and war
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Woodstock, Vt.: The Elm Tree press
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: edited by Charles L. Dana.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Patriotic poetry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: With the American declaration of war in the first week of April 1917 the rift in American poetry between the avant garde and the traditionalists widened. As in England, this rift also betrayed political differences.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Our glorious heritage
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: compiled by Charles Seddon Evans ; introduction by the very Reverend H.C. Beeching.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Children's poetry, English
Patriotic poetry, English
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Introduction: "War, therefore, supplies two opportunities to the poet: he can articulate voice to the love of country and the love of freedom and any other special idea that animates either combatant, such as respect for a nation's pledged word or the protection of the weak against the strong; and he can also celebrate the heroic exploits of armies and individuals which every war calls forth."

From Shaw Bibliography: Introduction in Description. The German invasion of Belgium in the first week of the war is cited by English writers, historians, and politicians as the precipitating cause of England's entry into the war, and would be used thereafter to justify the moral authority of the Entente. Even Bertrand Russell would speak of the "wrong" inflicted on Belgium. (But cf. Robert Graves, "Good-bye to All That," rev. ed. [Garden City: Doubleday, 1957], Chapter XVII, esp. 182ff.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hit by the war
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gabe, Marie-Rose
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Author signed presentation copy.

Summary: "But it's riling to a chap and dreadful humbling / To 'ave a lady in a tram car, rise and stand / When all a bloke has got, is fingers orf 'is 'and!" ("Tommy Grumbles"); "I appreciate your grumble, Tommy! / Yet tell us what to do! / We want to do you honour / (Who are maimed by 'fighting through'!)" ("A 'Ministering Angel' Replies")

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: nativity
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kipling, Rudyard , 1865-1936
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Page & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: PR4854 .N24 1917
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: This limited edition pamphlet poem was published when the war was not going well for England. Kipling (1865-1936), Nobel laureate, lost his son in 1915 to the war on the Western Front.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: crown of amaranth
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1914-1918--Poetry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Subtitle: being a collection of poems to the memory of the brave and gallant gentlemen who have given their lives for Great & Greater Britain. Dedication: "To the Memory of Rupert Brooke": "...Deaf to the roar of battle, yet shall he / Hear what the grass says when a light breeze stirs.... / Mothers of men, that men may still be free, / Yield now their sons--Chief Poet, own and see / That song has spared not hers!"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First poems
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Plowman, Max , 1883-1941
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Copy has bookplate: Ex libris Walter De la Mare.

From Shaw Bibliography: Plowman (1883-1941) served on the Western Front and wrote a bitter book about the war. "First Poems" offers a useful contrast with the consequences of experience on the Western Front.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: England's boys
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Renshaw, C. A. (Constance Ada)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: The title went through two editions within one year. Trench warfare being what it was in the Great War, the airmen became the avatar of knighthood, as is indicated by Miss Renshaw's "Air Men." (But cf. above, p. 13, entry 180).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Swords and flutes
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Seymour, William Kean , 1887-
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw bibliography: In style and statement there is no greater contrast than between Seymour's "The Deathless Dead" and Owen's "Anthem...."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Valour and vision
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: arranged and edited by Jacqueline T. Trotter.
"The intention is to present the poet as the historian, and to illustrate the different aspects and phases of the war by contemporary poetry."--Pref. note.
Includes index.
Poem pasted on end paper.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1914-1918--Poetry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: "The outbreak of war evoked a chorus of patriotic verse, but with some noble exceptions it gave us little of permanent value"--Prefatory Note (written from Jerusalem, 1919). Includes Kipling, Binyon, Newbolt, McCrae, Nichols, Brooke, Sorley, Seeger, Thomas, de la Mare, de Stein, et al, but not Wilfred Owen.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: child's ABC of the war
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Whitworth, Geoffrey Arundel , 1883-1951
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War, 1914-1918--Juvenile literature
D522.7 .W5 1914
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: Inscribed "Xmas 1914." Intended for three-year-olds. Whitworth (1883-1951) also wrote criticism, drama, and fiction. Covers the role of the colonies ("loyal and true"), the Allies (France, Russia, Belgium), the officers ("brilliant and daring"), the private ("God bless him"), etc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Swollen-headed William
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lucas, E. V. (Edward Verrall) , 1868-1938
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: text adapted by E. V. Lucas ; drawings adapted by Geo. Morrow.
Parody on Struwwelpeter by Heinrich Hoffmann-Donner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: William , 1859-1941
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Shaw Bibliography: English propaganda assumes literacy in its audience. Here English critic and biographer E.V. Lucas (1868-1938) offers a political parody of Heinrich Hoffman's "Struwwelpeter." Methuen also published patriotic speeches and Kipling's Great War writings.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Girl's own annual
The Girl's own paper. Vol. 1-43
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Children's literature.
Serialized fiction.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary: Published in Britain from 1880 until 1956, The Girl's Own Annual, alternatively known as the Girl's Own Paper, was a story paper catering to girls and young women. It includes serialized fiction, advice columns, current events, life and fashion tips for its readers. The issues published during World War I were titled The Girls Own Paper and Woman's Magazine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Use of this item is provided for non-commercial, personal, educational, and research use only. For information about the copyright and reproduction rights for this item, please contact Special Collections & Archives, Florida State University Libraries, Tallahassee, Florida.
